comments: Also denominators in expansion of Psi(x).zeta(2n)/(2i * ( log(1-i)-log(1+i) ))^(2n) = zeta(2n)/(-i*log(-1))^(2n). - _Eric Desbiaux_, Dec 12 2008a(0)=2. - _Artur Jasinski_, Mar 11 2010a(n) is always divisible by 3 (by the Von Staudt-Clausen theorem, see A002445).A comment due to G. Campbell: The original approach taken by Euler was to derive the infinite product for sin(Pi*x)/(Pi*x) equal to (1 - x^2/1^2) (1 - x^2/2^2)(1 - x^2/3^2) ... treating sin(Pi*x)/(Pi*x) as if it were a polynomial. Differentiating the logarithm of both sides and equating coefficients gives all of the zeta function values for 2, 4, 6, 8, .... - _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 29 2015

formula: Sum[2/(n^2 + 1), {n, 1, Infinity}] = Pi*Coth[Pi]-1. 2*Sum[(-1)^(k + 1)/n^(2*k), {k, 1, Infinity}] = 2/(n^2+1). - Shmuel Spiegel (shmualm(AT)hotmail.com), Aug 13 2001zeta(2n) = Sum_{k >= 1} k^(-2n) = (-1)^(n-1)*B_{2n}*2^(2n-1)*Pi^(2n)/(2n)!.a(n) = -A046988(n)*A010050(n)*A002445(n)/(A009117(n)*A000367(n))a(n) = sqrt(denominator(sum_{i=1...infinity} A000005(i)/i^2n)). - _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Jan 19 2012Sum_{k >= 1} zeta(2k)*x^(2k) = (1-Pi*x*cot(Pi*x))/2. - _Chris Boyd_, Dec 21 2015
